speaker: Clinician
text: So, through the interpreter, I'm double-checking: you're drawing up 0.25 milligrams of semaglutide every Sunday morning, right?

speaker: Clinician
text: Store it in the fridge door, not the freezer, and start a new pen after four doses.

speaker: Clinician
text: If nausea hits, sip ginger tea and eat small dry crackers before injecting, rather than skipping.

speaker: Clinician
text: Also, because you’d like to conceive, we’ll stop semaglutide the moment a home test turns positive.

speaker: Clinician
text: Insurance pushed back, saying weight-loss drugs aren’t essential; I filed an urgent appeal, but approval may take ten days.

speaker: Clinician
text: Meanwhile, you still have the starter pen, so no missed doses should occur this month.

speaker: Patient
text: Um, through the interpreter, I’ll try to explain—yesterday the sugar numbers were jumping around, 168 before dal bhat, then I forgot to prick after lunch because a rush job came in, and by bedtime the meter said 212. I did take my usual forty units, but my stomach felt heavy, almost queasy, like when the bus ride is too long. The new shot, I mean semaglutide, makes me less hungry, which is nice, yet the scale barely moved. And I’m worried if the pharmacy delays again; I can’t keep asking my cousin to chase papers. What if the pen runs out early? Money is tight, you know, already.

speaker: Clinician
text: Could you walk me through yesterday’s readings—pre-breakfast, after lunch, and at bedtime—so I can adjust your insulin?
